title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for inspection. Schedule A and Section 10(a) outline the required information for the registration statement and prospectus. Regulations issued by the commission further detail the requirements. The Securities Act of 1933 mandates registration of securities with the SEC before public offering. The registration statement includes a prospectus and Part II for inspection. Schedule A and Section 10(a) specify required information. Regulations provide further details. Exempted transactions include private placements and intrastate offerings. Securities Exchange Act of 1934 focuses on disclosure through periodic reports to the commission. The Exchange Act of 1934 requires issuers with securities traded on a national exchange or meeting certain criteria to register with the SEC and file periodic reports. Sections 12 and 13 outline the filing requirements for detailed statements, annual, and quarterly reports. Section 14 covers proxy solicitation, with some exemptions available. The SEC has issued regulations to specify these reporting requirements. The SEC requires companies to file reports containing all material information for investors. Failure to disclose material information is actionable under Section 18(a) of the Securities Exchange Act. The Investment Company Act of 1940 protects investors who use others to manage their investments. The Investment Company Act of 1940 protects investors by requiring investment companies to register with the SEC, file specified information, and comply with certain provisions to participate in securities activities. It also limits affiliations and interests of directors, officers, and employees, and mandates filing of reports and financial statements. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as someone who advises others on securities. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as someone who advises others on securities and must be registered with the SEC. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 was enacted to deter insider trading in the securities markets by increasing sanctions against violators. Insider trading refers to trading while in possession of material information. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 increased sanctions against insider trading to deter violations, allowing for civil penalties up to three times the profit gained or loss avoided. This act expanded penalties for those who fail to prevent insider trading and increased jail terms for criminal securities law violations. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988, signed into law by the President after debates in the 100th Congress, expanded civil penalties for insider trading control persons, increased jail terms and fines for securities law violations, initiated a bounty program for informants, and required broker-dealers and investment advisers to prevent inside information misuse. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 aimed to address frivolous shareholder lawsuits related to fraud, mismanagement, and nondisclosure, ultimately leading to shareholder losses. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) limits shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by appointing a lead plaintiff, restricting individuals from being lead plaintiffs in multiple class actions, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, providing a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, implementing proportionate liability, and requiring auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. This act was enacted in response to perceived frivolous shareholder lawsuits involving fraud, mismanagement, and shareholder losses. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) aims to limit shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by setting criteria for bringing securities fraud cases, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, and requiring auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. It was enacted in response to perceived abuses of securities fraud litigation and aims to prevent plaintiffs from circumventing the requirements set out by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA). The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was enacted in response to corporate scandals like Enron and WorldCom. It establishes a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, restricts accounting firms from providing certain services to companies they audit, and requires additional disclosures for public companies and their officers. The act also addresses securities fraud and internal issues. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 establishes a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board supervised by the SEC, restricts accounting firms from providing certain services to audited companies, and requires additional disclosures for public companies and their officers. Dodd-Frank, enacted in response to the financial downturn, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry through Title VII's regulation of over-the-counter swaps markets and jurisdictional parameters for the CFTC and SEC. Dodd-Frank, enacted in response to the financial downturn of 1929, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry. Title VII of Dodd-Frank regulates the over-the-counter swaps markets and sets jurisdictional parameters for the CFTC and SEC. Title IX introduces new powers for the SEC, including the creation of an Office of the Investor Advocate and a whistleblower bounty program for securities fraud disclosures. Other provisions in Title IX aim to increase investor protection by expanding regulation of credit rating agencies and requiring shareholder votes on executive compensation packages. The Dodd-Frank Act includes provisions to increase investor protection, such as regulating credit rating agencies, requiring shareholder votes on executive compensation, and establishing oversight for public accounting firms. Additionally, the STOCK Act prohibits Members of Congress from trading stocks based on inside information received through their positions. The STOCK Act prohibits Members of Congress from trading stocks based on inside information received through their positions. The JOBS Act aims to ease securities reporting requirements to encourage funding for small businesses and startups. Title I and Title III of the JOBS Act are of note, with Title I applying to emerging growth companies and Title III concerning crowdfunding. Title III of the JOBS Act exempts certain companies from registration requirements under the 1933 Securities Act if specific conditions are met, including limits on the amount of securities sold to investors and the requirement to use a funding portal for transactions.
